title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: The hunt took place either on the moors abovethe Cauldshiels Loch, or over some of the hills on the estate of Gala,and we had commonly, ere we returned, hares enough to supply the wife ofevery farmer that attended, with soup for a week following.

title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: Walter (you remember my wading into Cauldshiels Loch to     save his little frigate from wreck) is now a Cornet of six feet     two inches in your Irish 18th Hussars; the regiment is now at     Cork, and will probably be next removed to Dublin, so you will     see your old friend with a new face; be-furred, be-feathered, and     be-whiskered in the highest military _ton_.

title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: Walter (you remember my wading into Cauldshiels Loch to     save his little frigate from wreck) is now a Cornet of six feet     two inches in your Irish 18th Hussars; the regiment is now at     Cork, and will probably be next removed to Dublin, so you will     see your old friend with a new face; be-furred, be-feathered, and     be-whiskered in the highest military _ton_.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The Huntly Burn, a mountain brook from which the house was named, finds its way from Cauldshiels Loch through the Rhymer's Glen, " famous in tradition as the scene of Thomas the Rhymer's interviews with the Queen of Fairy."

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: The hunt took place either on the moors above the Cauldshiels Loch, or over some of the hills on the estate of Gala, and we had commonly, ere we returned, hares enough to supply the wife of every farmer that attended, with soup for a week following.
